DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
1

development, implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency has not provided reunification services to parent.
Investigation On 6/16/25 Complainant reported to DCWL that the agency had
not provided reunification services to Parent 1. Complainant
stated Foster Care Worker “flat out refused resources and
services”. The case had been open over a year and a petition to
terminate parental rights was filed. One of the reasons for filing
termination was due to a lack of housing, which the agency failed
to assist with. The agency told Parent 1 that after completing a
three-month substance use program, they would provide a
housing voucher. But that never happened. Parent 1 reported a
history of domestic violence to the agency, but did not receive any
services to address it. Complainant stated the case has dragged
out intentionally to keep the children in care. Complainant
disagreed with the children being in foster care at all, and
indicated there was no abuse or neglect, and the children should
not have been removed from Parent 1. Complainant stated Parent
1 was in full compliance with their treatment plan. Services that
had not been provided include drug testing, housing, counseling,
and visitation.
Interviews:
Parent 1 was contacted via email on 6/16/25 and provided with
questions regarding the allegation. Parent 1 reported several
concerns regarding MDHHS Children’s Services and the
investigation that brought the children into care. However, those
concerns are outside of the purview of DCWL. Parent 1 also
expressed concerns regarding the police, prosecutor and court,
which are also outside of the scope of DCWL. Regarding Bethany
Christian Services, Parent 1 stated Foster Care Worker refused to
provide her with services. Parent 1 indicated she spoke with
Foster Care Supervisor, but it did not help the situation. Parent 1
also stated her lawyer was not doing anything to help her. Parent
1 stated she had not received assistance with housing, food,
transportation, jobs, clothing, domestic violence counseling,
divorce proceedings, or medical care. Parent 1 recalled she had
received $20 in gas cards, but that was all. Parent 1 reported she
set up her own services through Arbor Circle, as well as therapy,
rehabilitation, transportation, and substance abuse treatment.
Parent 1 stated she was in compliance with the treatment plan,
2

but did not do “every single thing” because the agency wasn’t
providing services. Parent 1 stated she did not have phone calls
with her children while incarcerated. Parent 1 stated there were a
few times when she arrived at the agency for parenting time, and
was told it was cancelled due to her husband’s behavior. Parent 1
felt degraded by the workers and felt that no one would help her.
Parent 1 reported that she was going to forensic fluids for
substance use testing, but someone told her she did not have to
since she was also doing testing at a medical clinic. The agency
then changed their mind and denied ever agreeing to that plan.
Parent 1 stated she believed the relative caregiver for her son had
a household member that was using drugs and drove with her
child in the car. Parent 1 reported this to the agency, but the
agency did not do anything. Parent 1 stated she asked for a new
worker but continues to have the same one.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) was contacted by email on
6/26/25 and interviewed via video call on 6/30/25. FCS reported
she met with Parent 1 the week prior. Parent 1 had some
questions about the recommendation for termination. FCS
explained that Parent 1 had not participated at all when the case
began in April 2024 and failed to follow through with
recommended services. Parent 1 was upset because she felt that
she completed everything she needed to do. When FCS asked
about services completed, Parent 1 did not have clear answers.
FCS explained what was needed in order to move past
termination and keep working towards reunification. FCS stated
they had a lot of repeat conversations as Parent 1 seemed to
have difficulty understanding. However, the bottom line was that
the termination recommendation occurred due to the case being
over a year old, Parent 1 being incarcerated for six months, in
rehab for three months, and refusing to complete services after
being released.
FCS reported that Foster Care Worker (FCW) drove Parent 1
around to obtain drug screen result documentation; to help show
she was compliant in that area. FCW received a packet of papers,
with a note on top stating that Parent 1 did not want the drug
screen results shared with FCW. As a result of Parent 1 not
sharing information, she is considered to not be following the
treatment plan. FCS stated that to her knowledge Parent 1 had
not requested a worker change.
Program Manager was contacted by email on 6/26/25 and
interviewed via video call on 6/30/25. Program Manager stated
she had never received a complaint about FCW. Program
3

Manager also stated she never received a request from Parent 1
to change the case worker, nor had she received a grievance from
Parent 1. Program Manager stated to her knowledge Parent 1 was
not difficult to work with. Parent 1 would yell and scream at the
worker when she became upset, but she would calm down
quickly. Program Manager noted that some parenting time was
not completed, as the oldest child was refusing to visit with Parent
1.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was contacted by email on 6/26/25
and interviewed via video call on 6/30/25. Follow-up occurred with
FCW on 7/21/25 and 7/29/25 for additional information. FCW
reported Parent 1 was released from jail in February 2025 and
entered treatment at that time. FCW spoke with Parent 1 and her
therapist about completing the 90-day program, and what other
services were available while there, and post discharge. Parent 1
completed the program in May 2025 and moved in with a relative.
FCW visited the home, found it to be appropriate, and discussed
having the children live there. Parent 1 inquired about a housing
voucher through Family Reunification Planning and was informed
one would be provided after all other reunification barriers were
removed. The additional barriers included substance abuse,
employment, and domestic violence. Once those services were
complete, a housing voucher would be issued. Parent 1 was
working with a treatment program where she received therapy and
had a sobriety coach. FCW maintained contact with the sobriety
coach to ensure Parent 1 was engaged and benefiting from
services. Parent 1 continued to provide drug screens through the
treatment program, as well as through the Methadone clinic.
However, FCW was unable to obtain results from the clinic. The
agency received a 54-page packet from the clinic, but the packet
did not have the drug screen results and the front page stated that
the client (Parent 1) only wanted the dates released to the agency
and not the results. Currently Parent 1 is screened twice weekly
through two different facilities.
FCW reported visits were never withheld. Visitation occurred twice
per week after being released from jail. However, one of the
children refused to visit about every other week while visits were
at the rehabilitation facility. Since the visits moved to the agency,
the child has been consistently attending. FCW noted there was a
court order regarding visits which stated Parent 1 needed to arrive
an hour early, in order to complete a drug screen and confirm visit
attendance.
4

FCW reported a lack of housing was not the main reason that a
termination trial was scheduled. Although housing was still a
barrier. The agency provided Parent 1 with a list of housing
resources, but a voucher could not be provided until all other
barriers were addressed as part of the procedure for West
Michigan Partnership for Children. This was explained to Parent 1
on a few occasions when she had asked for a voucher. Parent 1
asked FCW for a letter stating that housing was her last barrier.
FCW did not provide the letter, as that information was inaccurate.
Compliance with services and sobriety needs to occur for six
months before the agency can report the barrier was fully
addressed. Regarding the statement that Parent 1 was told the
agency would not pursue termination if she completed treatment,
FCW stated that was not how the conversation went. FCW spoke
with Parent 1 about termination being recommended due to the
length of the time the case had been open, and the lack of
progress. FCW informed Parent 1 that due to being incarcerated
and in treatment for a significant portion of the case, it was
possible the termination recommendation would be denied in
order to allow Parent 1 more time to continue working on services.
Lastly, regarding Complainant’s concern about Household
Member at the relative caregiver’s home, FCW reported this
concern was voiced early in the case. Parent 1 initially reported
that she was in a car accident when she was younger and it was
caused by Household Member. Parent 1 told FCW that she did
not trust Household Member and did not want him to drive her
child around. FCW stated Household Member reported he had a
substance abuse issue, for which he received treatment.
Household Member reported being sober and actively working
through recovery since 2019. In addition, Household Member
successfully completed probation for possession of substances.
FCW stated the agency received a statement from the treatment
program that reported Household Member was following the
program. A driving record was also obtained and found to be
current and valid. FCW did not report any concerns about
Household Member.
Documents reviewed:
• Court orders dated 12/4/24, and 3/4/25 indicated that
reasonable efforts were made to achieve permanency.
Services included scheduled intakes, parenting time, visit
coach, parenting specialist, drug screens, family team
meetings, housing assistance, parent nurturing referral, and
psychological evaluation.
5

• The 4/3/25 Updated Service Plan recommended
termination. A termination trial was adjourned 4/21/25, then
continued 6/11/25.
• Parenting-time plan required two hours of visitation per
week, in the office, supervised. Parenting-time case
contacts were reviewed and found parenting-time to be
offered as required. However, there were some cancelled
visits at the beginning of the case due to parent
incarceration, parent not confirming they would attend visit,
and youth refusing to visit.
• 7/2/2025 Parent Agency Treatment Plan (PATP) noting
areas of need for Parent 1:
o Substance Abuse- Goal: gain and maintain sobriety.
“Partial” Progress: Parent 1 successfully completed
90-day program on 5/29/25. While at the program,
Parent 1 engaged in individual and group therapy,
Narcotics Anonymous Meetings, and random drug
screens. After inpatient treatment, Parent 1 began
receiving services and therapy, along with utilizing a
sobriety coach. Parent 1 had negative substance
screens in May and June 2025.
o Emotional Stability Behavior- Goal: Engage in
services to address mental health and well-being.
“Partial” Progress: Parent 1 provided documentation
to verify attendance in counseling in May, July,
August, and September 2024. After exiting inpatient
treatment in May 2025, Parent 1 began individual
therapy sessions. The therapist reported Parent 1
was engaged in her sessions. Parent 1 continues to
utilize medication as prescribed by her doctor.
o Parenting Skills- “Partial Progress”: Parent 1
attended 21 of 24 scheduled parenting times during
the report period. Successfully completed Parenting
After Trauma course. Utilizing parenting time
specialist during visits to build parenting skills-
including redirecting the children when they fight, as
it was observed they did not listen to her during
parenting time.
o Domestic Relations- Goal: engage in services to
address domestic violence and healthy relationships.
Parent 1 and Parent 2 reported no history of
domestic violence. Parent 1 has since reported
some incidents and expressed a desire to divorce.
Parent 1 was working with the Women’s Resource
Center to navigate that process. Ongoing
assessment in this area due to Parent 2 being
6

incarcerated and no progress from Parent 1 toward
divorce at this time.
o Social Support System- Goal: Utilize community
resources to establish a positive support system.
Progress: Identified two support people in her life.
o Employment- Progress: Parent 1 continues to seek
employment and notify agency of efforts. Parent 1 is
aware that employment verification will need to be
provided monthly.
o Child Characteristics- Goal: Parent 1 will participate
in all of her children’s services. Progress: One youth
is engaged in therapy. No indication if Parent 1 is
participating. Trauma Informed Parenting strategies
were recommended with this youth.
o Resource Availability/Management- Goal: Utilize
services and resources to meet financial needs.
Progress: A budget will be completed with Parent 1
once she gains employment.
• Service documents:
o 6/5/24 visit coach summary, indicated “significant
concerns” and “some concerns” in all areas
assessed. The recommendation was for Parent 1 to
attend all parenting time, abstain from substances,
and be fully present. Further recommended to
participate in Parenting Time Specialist program.
o 5/9/25 letter confirming admitted to treatment on
2/28/25.
o Letter indicating treatment completed 5/28/25.
o Parenting After Trauma Class- 6/24/25 summary
from instructor reported that Parent 1 was engaged
in class and made up two sessions that she missed.
o On 6/4/25 FCW drove Parent 1 to treatment center
to obtain records of treatment prior to incarceration.
A cover letter for drug test results dated 6/4/25
indicated “patient did not want results shown. Only
dates”
• Family Team Meetings:
o 2/24/25 Parent 1 was unable to participate from jail.
Placement of youth with grandparents was doing
well. Youth was engaged in therapy and working
with behavioral specialist.
o 4/16/25 Discussed PATP with Parent 1 and plan
regarding services due to termination hearing.
Parent 1 inquired about separating her treatment
plan from Parent 2.
7

o 7/17/25 Termination hearing was adjourned.
Discussed with Parent 1 that she had an extra
month to comply with services because of
adjournment. Addressed relative caregiver concerns.
• Relative Placement documents were reviewed.
o An MDHHS-5770 was completed on 4/19/24 and
approved placement with the relative caregivers.
o A DHHS-3130A was completed on 4/21/25. The
evaluation assessed Household Members criminal
and substance history. The placement was
recommended and did not require an exception
request.
o A DHHS clearance for Household Member dated
4/1/25 indicated a report to Children’s Services on
9/23/20 regarding drug use and transporting his child
while under the influence. Household Member stated
he was never made aware of that allegation and did
not receive services from DHHS.
o A Michigan Driving Record clearance dated 5/27/25
for Household Member indicated his license was
valid. The record showed a violation on 10/6/15 due
to substance use, a speeding ticket on 10/21/20, and
a minor traffic accident on 2/7/24 that did not involve
substances.
o In a relative placement home study dated 4/8/25,
Household Member reported he had been in
recovery for over three years and continued to
receive treatment. The safety plan indicated
Household Member would not be alone to provide
care for the child placed in the home. Household
Member would not be under the influence of
substances or obtain substances while living in the
home and would not use or be under the influence
while in the presence of the child in the home.
o A Safety Plan update, dated 7/23/25 outlined that
Household Member would not obtain or be under the
influence of any substances, if under the influence
the relative caregivers would ask him to leave; no
drugs would be allowed in the home; Household
Member would updated his clearances annually;
Household Member was able to provide care and
transportation for the child; Household Member
would not care for or transport the child if under the
influence.
o An undated letter from a therapist at Cherry Health
verified that Household Member began substance
8

use treatment in 2019. The therapist reported
Household Member continues to attend the center
daily for care and participates in individual therapy.
The therapist indicated these services would be
ongoing.
o A court order dated 2/21/25 indicated Household
Member began probation on 8/21/23 and his
compliance “warrants an early discharge from
probation”. Household Member’s probation was
discharged as of 2/21/25.
Analysis No violation was found. Based on interviews and case documents
reviewed, the agency has identified the appropriate needs of
Parent 1 and familiarized her with the items required in order to be
compliant. Parent 1 received substance abuse treatment, therapy,
parenting time, parenting class, and assistance with initiating
divorce proceedings. Due to Parent 1’s incarceration, her
participation in services was delayed. However, there was no
evidence to indicate the agency failed to provide services toward
reunification.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
